Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2009 03:20AM ubuana wrote: I have had 2 lumps removed from my left breast.  Both I found myself, one only months after mamo and ultrasound missed it.  Both were considered benign and one was thought to be an enlarged lymph node.  Both were IDC.  I do not want to scare you at all, but i also have a strong family history of cancer (same breast, same age as mother).  Please at least do a needle biopsy and be sure.  I just did a double mast with recon.  I had even more cancer in the left breast that had all the problems.  I at least came out with clear nodes.  It is always better to catch it early.  I no longer trust mamo and sonos completely (now I don't need them).  My opinion is they only help find suspicious areas.  I do not think they can be used to accurately diagnose if a lump is malignant or not.
Posts.Title: Need help understanding test results...please! amypat Ina

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 08:37PM ubuana wrote: If the doctor thought you had phyllodes tumor, the second piece that he removed MAY have been to ensure that he had a clean margin on a fast growing tumor type.  If he had been correct with the diagnosis, he would probably done you a lifesaving action to ensure that nothing was missed. The sad thing is that the path report seems to identify it as benign, I think.  What I do not undersand is why a needle biopsy was not done first or why it would not be accurate? I have had 2 lumpectomies and just finished a double mast.  I did have cancer.  Each lump was removed upon discovery without a needle biopsy.  Each was removed with extra margins until they were clear.  But still the cancer slipped through.  That is when I decided I had to go to the extreem while my nodes were still clear.  Cancer is sneaky, it seems like he thought for some reason there was a high risk for you.  I would find out why he felt that way.  Or maybe he was way to over cautious, It would be hard to tell from here.  What were the discussions like before the surgery?  I guess I am repeating the prior poster, talk to the doctor about why he chose to do what he did.  It sounds like he had a difficulty in the surgery, though the bleeding could be just an unfortunate complication.  You have a lot to ask him.  I would also ask for the post sugical report where he should have given a rundown of how the surgery proceeded and any issues encountered.
